column1: I continue to work directly with Democratic and Republican colleagues to fight for desperately needed relief but House & Senate leadership must demonstrate the same commitment that Virginians have shown for months. The American people shouldn't have to shoulder this work alone.

As the holiday season begins I hope that the spirit of service that has defined Virginians’ response to the pandemic will only grow. While neighbors continue to lift each other up the U.S. House and Senate MUST pass a new negotiated COVID-19 relief package.

As we give thanks for the blessings in our lives we also know that for many of our neighbors across #VA07 this Thanksgiving may be one of the most difficult in their lifetimes. My heart is with all the families who will be mourning a loss this week. https://t.co/jFDXgRupwC

This is only one of the ways that the Lower Drug Costs Now Act would fight rising drug prices. The bill also gives Medicare Part D the power to negotiate directly with drug companies and those lower prices would also be available to Americans with private insurance. (5/5)

The AIM price is a volume-weighted average of the price of prescription drugs in Australia Canada France Germany Japan & the United Kingdom. If there's no AIM price for a certain drug the max in the United States would be capped at 85% of the avg. manufacturer price. (4/5)

For drug price negotiations between PBMs and big pharmaceutical companies in the United States the Lower Drug Costs Now Act would set the max price at 120% of the average international market or AIM price. (3/5)

Why does it matter what someone pays for a prescription drug in another country?  The Lower Drug Costs Now Act which I cosponsored and voted to pass would set max prices for U.S. drugs based on average prices in comparable countries. (2/5)

U.S. drug prices are nearly 4 times higher than the average prices in similar nations like Australia & Germany. Even accounting for rebates Americans pay more than their counterparts overseas – you can visit https://t.co/WmLMolbx8F to see comparisons for your medication. (1/5)
